summary: An email from attorney Lilly Ann Sanchez to Alexander Acosta, then U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, regarding Jeffrey Epstein. The email includes an attachment (2608.pdf) and contains standard legal disclaimers regarding tax advice and attorney-client privilege.

persons.name: Lilly Ann Sanchez
persons.context: The sender of the email to Alexander Acosta regarding Jeffrey Epstein, identifying herself as an attorney with the firm Fowler White Burnett P.A.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: The recipient of the email, who was the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida at the time.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email, indicating the communication pertains to him.

connections.description: Sanchez, an attorney, is sending an email regarding Jeffrey Epstein to Acosta, the U.S. Attorney.
Sanchez is communicating with a federal prosecutor about Epstein, suggesting a legal or professional interest in the matter.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, is being contacted regarding Epstein, indicating his office's involvement in the Epstein case.

events.title: Email Regarding Epstein Sent to U.S. Attorney
events.description: Attorney Lilly Ann Sanchez sends an email to U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta regarding Jeffrey Epstein, with an attached document.

keyFacts: On December 7, 2007, attorney Lilly Ann Sanchez emailed U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta regarding Jeffrey Epstein.
The email included an attachment named '2608.pdf', the contents of which are not specified in this text.
The communication is marked as attorney privileged and confidential, intended only for the named recipient.
The email contains standard IRS Circular 230 tax advice disclaimers, indicating the sender's firm handles tax matters.
This document shows direct communication between a private attorney and the lead federal prosecutor (Acosta) about Epstein during the investigation period.
